campaign.story:
A Father’s Son is story-spinoff based on author Henry Chang’s crime novel series featuring NYPD Detective Jack Yu. Set in the early '90s when local street gangs terrorized Manhattan’s Chinatown, our story centers on Detective Jack Yu investigating the murder of a teenage boy involved in a turf war. Amidst the broad distrust and racial divide between the Chinatown community and NYPD, our lone lawman searches for a nondescript immigrant family to deliver a shattering message that also brings forth his own conflicted relationship with Jack’s father.  
Since 2006, Henry Chang’s posters of his crime drama book series, Chinatown Beat, Year of The Dog, Red Jade, and Death Money were displayed at my two favorite NYC Chinatown restaurants: 69 Bayard and Wo Hop City. The posters caught my attention for years until I purchased his first book titled Chinatown Beat.  
After reading the first installment, I became enamored with the fictional character Jack Yu, a NYPD Detective torn between justice and the injustice to his community. He was a born-and-bred New Yorker with a New Yawk accent trying to do good. It was the first time reading about a Chinese-American protagonist who wasn’t an American stereotype. Jack wasn’t a cook, waiter, deliveryman, an herbalist, railroad worker, opioid dealer, martial artist, monk or Manchu.   
Positive Asian-American role models were invisible unless it was Bruce Lee, Jackie Chan and Jet Li, or another martial art figure. Only little known-actor Dennis Gong Dun came close portraying a Chinese-American protagonist in Year of the Dragon as Herbert Kwong, and as Wang Chi in Big Trouble in Little China. But that was only around 1980s.
Not all of us know Kung-Fu - The Slanted Screen
Today, thanks to organizations like Gold House and box-office hits like Crazy Rich Asians, there’s a genuine opportunity for good stories with tangible Asian-American characters. It’s been 13 years since the release of Chinatown Beat and I felt this was the right time to bring Jack Yu to light in our story, A Father’s Son. 
I grew up watching Hong Kong '90s films. The three films I wrote and directed, Love Express, Confucius Plaza, and The Last Tip were inspired by Hong Kong’s cinematic style and natural realism -- which have been showcased at the Museum of Chinese in America and Comcast's Xfinity Lunar New Year collection.   
Films by Patrick Xi Hao Chen
With A Father’s Son I want to direct it as a film noir with reference to Johnnie To’s PTU (2003) and Election (2005). I want to exhibit the grittiness of New York’s Chinatown with the Cantonese essence that will simulate 1994.
The first step is to hire professional actors who can speak that dialect. The second is to collaborate with a cinematographer that can capture the vision. And lastly, location, location and location. A talented location manager and set designer will help us camouflage the slowly gentrifying 2019 NYC Chinatown into its 1994 iconic setting. In this Sinovision interview, Henry and I speak a bit about the change in Chinatown through the years with the cast of The Last Tip.
Producing a film can be challenging an expensive, especially one set in the early 1990s. We've enlisted help from as many talented individuals who could generously offer up their time and effort to make this project a reality. But favors do have their limits. That's why we need your help. 
Every contribution will go towards the creation of A Father's Son in its entirety -- from pre-production to distribution. This includes reimbursing actors, crew members, editors, sound designers, composers, and all the many specialized roles needed to get this project off the ground, as well as film festival submission fees and network marketing.
Our hopes is that A Father’s Son will gain enough interest to have Henry Chang’s books developed into a network series. It’s a long shot but audiences are now hungering for diverse original shows. After nearly 2 decades, Henry Chang will finally get a chance to see his characters come to life.
Click any of the links above to connect with us and help spread the word to raise awareness about this project. Every like, post, tweet and share could lead more awesome backers to our campaign and help us reach our funding goal.
campaign.risks:
Risks and challenges
This isn't our first campaign and while we are confident in our abilities as creators, we recognize that there may be unforeseeable complications that may arise from production, scheduling, or health issues. Whatever they may be, we're committed to facing them head on and delivering a film you can be proud of having supported.

If you have any concerns, feel free to get in touch with us either here on Kickstarter, or through the links below. We're more than happy to answer any questions you may have about the project.

Facebook: https://www.facebook.com/DetectiveJackYuOfficial

updates.update_content:
For a Limited Time
Available for purchase "A Father's Son" postcards, t-shirt, poster, and signed paperback copies from Chinatown author Henry Chang at https://cxhfilms.bigcartel.com
"A portion of the proceeds of each sale will go towards the NY Chinatown community, and help support additional festivals cost - yes it does add up!"

We're "More Than Asian"
Author Henry Chang opens himself on his upbringing, becoming a writer, and the social changes of his beloved neighborhood NY Chinatown with More Than Asian.

Hello Backers and Friends,
Recently a lot has happened to our community with the rise of anti-Asian Violence, especially towards our elders, and the tragedy of 6 Asian women from the Atlanta Shooting. A few collective groups have started a GoFundMe campaign.  Support the AAPI Community Fund that will issue grants to trusted AAPI organizations working to rectify racial inequalities in society. 
Lost but Always be Remembered
Here it is!  A Father's Son official film poster designed by Yixin Cen and David Bettencourt capturing the essence of Henry Chang's Detective Jack Yu Investigation series!

Lucky Boys Podcast
This past week both Jason Chew (cinematographer) and I were invited to be guests on Lucky Boys Podcast hosted by Will Hue and Norman Lam. It's refreshing to do something creative during the pandemic, and talk to good people in person while practicing social distance.

What's Happening with Post-Production and Manhattan's Chinatown These Days?
Hi Everyone, 
A lot has happened since the last public update in May on Kickstarter. I hope everyone is safe during these unpredictable times. Both Henry and I are safe and well. We managed to get together to make this video on the current status of .

It has been surreal these past couple of months with Covid-19 affecting our livelihood, health, and the economy. Particularly in the news and social media there has been unprecedented xenophobic attacks toward Asians and Asian Americans. It is unforgivable. Let's not repeat history but learn from it instead. May is an important month for us Asian Americans. It's a time to reflect and unite. 
Recently, PBS and Center for Asian American Media (CAAM) released a new documentary series titled Asian Americans. It is the first documentary to exhibit Chinese, Japanese, Koreans, Indians, Filipinos, and others in American history. I highly recommended watching this limited series on PBS with your family and friends. Let's not forget the Oscar nominated documentary film which is now available for a limited time on .

campaign.story:
Woodpecker Pie will sell delicious, sweet and savory hand pies out of The Mothlight, the best music venue and bar in Asheville, NC. 
Jon & Amanda Hency, Matt Bailey, & Vincent Gagnon taste test Woodpecker Pie at The Mothlight
Our Story
Between the two of us we have three decades of restaurant experience - both front and back of the house. We're more than ready to own our own business - to be our own bosses, and to put back into our community in a way that's true to our vision of what good food, good service, and good business practice can be. We're also both dads, and want to support our families in a way that's sustainable for the long term, feels (and tastes) good, and makes our kids proud. 
"Pie is Yummy," by Vincent's daughter Cora
Our Theory
Pie is easy to love; putting good food in a pie shell is only enhancing it. Pie is a comfort food, and that’s something we hope to offer our customers through our pies. 
Lemon strawberry chess pie
How It Will Work
This Kickstarter campaign will raise funds to build out a kitchen in what is currently an office space in The Mothlight, a music venue and bar in West Asheville. A "pie window" will allow customers to walk in off the street for a quick bite, and enable Mothlight customers to enjoy a hand pie while having a drink and watching some bands. 
For more detail about our set up, cooking methods, and menu you can read a Mountain Xpress profile here.
For visitors to The Mothlight, we offer the convenience of not having to interrupt their evening to leave the venue in order to eat something delicious and affordable. As the only business exclusively selling pies in Asheville, we also hope to be a destination spot - bringing Asheville residents and visitors to Haywood Road.
Signature Woodpecker pies
Our Pies are HAND Pies!
Our signature item will be hand pies. What are hand pies, you ask? Hand pies are personal size pies that fit into the palm of your hand, and can be consumed free of silverware. Don't worry, though, we'll also be offering whole 9" pies for holidays and special orders.
Woodpecker Pie will offer slow fast food. We'll have a small menu with staple pies - three savory options, and two sweet options - with seasonal specials. Our menu will always be guided by quality over quantity. We will use only high quality ingredients, locally-sourced when possible. We will never use anything factory-farmed. This will ensure that our pies are seasonal, and that they sustain our local food culture at the same time that they sustain our customers.
We want as many people as possible to feel that we offer something that they want to eat; that’s why we’ll always offer vegetarian and gluten free options. While we don’t currently have the capacity to offer a vegan pie option (we’d need to produce a third pie dough), we hope to do so in the future. Vegan pies are available, however, through special order.
Caramelized onion & kale pies
Our Neighborhood
We want the Pie Shop to be part of the West Asheville neighborhood. Part of that is having a price point that is accessible to people who live and work here in our community. By having a small staff - currently the two co-owners are the two employees - our customers will get to know us at the same time they’re getting to know our pies. This is our business, and we want to be here.
Our Request
$15,000 is a lot of money. Here's what we're going to use it for:
Legal fees & permits
Kitchen build-out, including possible electrical and plumbing 
Kitchen equipment 
Initial food order
Making caramelized onion & kale pies
Vincent & Cora
A view of the bar in The Mothlight, West Asheville
campaign.risks:
Risks and challenges
Because of our space and financial limitations, we've already streamlined our pie-making process as much as we can. 

Our combined years of restaurant experience - more than three decades - has enabled us to look back at various restaurant models and the obstacles they've come up against in terms of the market. 

At this point we think we have approached start-up in the most efficient way possible. We're going as small as we can without it hindering our chances of success.

We're confident that we've done our research, tested the waters, and perfected the pie crust.
Learn about accountability on Kickstarter

updates.update_content:
Dear Friends,
The remodel of the kitchen is done and all of the heavy equipment is in. Matt even built the service window into the kitchen door so that folks will be able to purchase their pies in the Mothlight's gallery space. 
We are scheduling our inspections over the next week and a half, so keep your fingers crossed for us that we'll get our certificate of occupancy SOON! As in, this month if all goes well. We've had a lot of surprises along the way so we're hesitant to throw a date out there, but we'll keep you posted on our progress.

Dear Woodpecker Pie Backers,
First of all, thanks again for your incredible support! We know we're long overdue for an update on our project, and have been partly waiting until we had more information to share.
We've had to push back our opening date several times due to permitting and buildout taking much longer than expected. This has been a learning process for both of us; opening a business - and particularly building out a brand new kitchen - requires a lot of steps and is dependent on a lot of different people, including contractors and permit office staff. 
We'll keep you posted on our progress, including a more specific open date when we have it. Feel free to reach out to us any time with your questions and suggestions.

campaign.story:
A new musical fever-dream by Nellie Tinder, Evelyn is a play about the consequences of being somebody, and the horror of being nobody.
The women of Pennsylvania are making good progress - with talk therapy, group therapy, dance therapy and their surreptitious visits to the surrounding druidical wood, when luminous film actress Evelyn Henries arrives and reeks havoc with her iridescent star quality.  Will the fortress hold?  Or will Evelyn's Magick destroy the fragile strands of sanity these women have left?  
Evelyn is a mash-up/ riff/ love letter to the classic take down tale,* the stranger comes to town story,** and every hidden memory we’ve ever written down in a notebook spliced and bitten off in a homey kind of way***.  The performers will use their voices and whatever catch as catch-can instruments we find to create a rich, multilayered and exclusively organic soundtrack. Nellie Tinder’s unique stylization of movement and text explores the relationship of reality to artifice, even in the most dramatic of situations. 
*See Othello, Cousin Bette, The Sweet Smell of Success, etc.
**See The Pied Piper, Playboy of the Western World, etc. 
***Like that embarrassing period in high school when you talked with an English accent.
The Bushwick Starr will present Evelyn in their spring season, February 21st to March 10th, 2012.
We have shown excerpts of Evelyn at the Obie-Award winning performance series Little Theater and the acclaimed Catch! Performance series, and have gotten overwhelmingly positive feedback about the work we’ve done so far.   We have a fantastic production team, incredible performers, and we need your help to make this production happen. Your contribution will help purchase our sets, costumes, and lights; secure rehearsal space, assist in our marketing and audience development, compensate the amazing team who is devoting their time and energy to this production, and HELP SECURE THE FUTURE OF NELLIE TINDER to continue to make work and grow as a company.  
Remember, Kickstarter is an all or nothing organization – this means if we don’t raise ALL of the $4,000 dollars we need we get absolutely nothing.  Please help us spread the word and thank you for your time and generosity.  
THE EVELYN TEAM
Written and Directed by Julia May Jonas
Composed by Jon Lundbom and Julia May Jonas
Produced by Andrew Dinwiddie and Regina Vorria
Choreography by Jennie MaryTai Liu
Production Design by Ryan Holsopple
Costume Design by Normandy Sherwood
Assistant Director Jess Barbagallo
OUR CAST
Kate Benson, Lisa Clair, Nikki Calonge, Zoe Geltman, Hannah Heller, Lucy Kaminsky, Jocelyn Kuritsky, Richard Saudek and Kate Schroeder. 
For more about Nellie Tinder please take a look at our website.
Or you can visit our facebook page.
ABOUT THE BUSHWICK STARR
The Bushwick Starr is a non-profit Presenting Organization and full-scale performance venue, dedicated to bringing a continuum of performance artists to the Bushwick, Brooklyn community. Focusing on the presentation of new and developing work in theater, dance, and puppetry, The Bushwick Starr offers a professional, supportive, and affordable space for both artists and audiences. They are a thriving theatrical venue, a vital neighborhood arts center, and a destination for exciting and engaging performance.

campaign.story:
ABOUT THE PROJECT
We are asking for your support in order to fully realize our debut exhibition. We have been rigorously creating work over the past year, and are ready to share it with the world! We’ve found the perfect venue in the Angel Orensanz Foundation, housed in a majestic synagogue built in the 1840’s. The exhibition would feature collaborative pieces as well as our individual work in the form of photographic prints and collages. We wish to spread the word far and wide and also hope to self-publish a catalogue of our work. Our hope is to make our opening a great celebration with all the bells and whistles. Help us make this happen!
ABOUT THE VENUE: ANGEL ORENSANZ FOUNDATION
The Angel Orensanz Foundation for the Arts was established in 1992 as an artistic and cultural resource open to artists, writers, thinkers and leaders from all over the world. Over the years it has welcomed and been inspired by Philip Glass and Spike Lee; Arthur Miller, Alexander McQueen, Salman Rushdie, Maya Angelou and Alexander Borovsky; Elie Wiesel and Chuck Close. One of the oldest synagogues in New York City, it is a Lower East Side Landmark.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
All donations will go directly towards production costs of exhibition and catalogue publication, as well as fees for all supporting personnel at opening. Your support is greatly appreciated.
Become Co-Curators with us!
with love,
Felix & Dexter

campaign.story:
Proximity, a Santa Barbara based 501(c)(3) non-profit theatre company, embarks on a journey this summer, a rebirth of the original piece Shandy Wilkes, written by Karina Richardson. Under the guidance of NYU Tisch School of the Arts graduates Kyra Lehman (Artistic Director), Ken Urbina (Executive & Musical Director), and Ms. Richardson (Co-Artistic Director, Actor, and Writer), company members are challenged to perform at professional levels incorporating experimental theatre techniques into traditional storytelling.  
This time around, we are approaching Shandy’s story with a smaller group of wildly focused young actors and musicians who share a common mission; to inspire people to connect to their bodies, themselves, and each other by vigorously exploring how alive we can be in our own skins. An intensive three week reworking of the show will prepare us for three performances at Center Stage Theater in Santa Barbara on August 10th, 11th, & 12th, followed by three performances at the Robert Moss Theatre in New York City on August 18th, 19th, & 20th.
By reaching our goal of $20,000, we’ll be able to cover the costs of pre-production, production, transportation, accommodations, rehearsal space, performance space, labor, and all the other real world expenses we must negotiate in order to do what we love to do. With a successful campaign, we won’t have to do anything during the rehearsal process but dive in, and that is priceless.
We owe everything to the strength of our community, and to those of you who have been with us from the start, we owe a special thanks to you.  Your continued generosity is what turns our passion and dreams into production, year after year. To those of you who are new to our company, support our cross-country venture and be rewarded by knowing you are helping a grassroots arts community grow! That won’t be your only reward of course…
To the right, you’ll find a list of our incentives, based on the amount of the contribution.   From song downloads to t-shirts, from show tickets to behind-the-scenes disposable camera reels, we took the time to create incentives we thought you would love. Because we care that you care about us.  Whether you're dying to have Proximity's Greatest Hits Album always on deck in the car, you've always wanted to be billed as the director of a high-class theatre production, or you’re a purist who just wants to give us ten bucks, we’re sure we have an incentive that’s right for you.
Thank you, from the bottom of our hearts, for supporting us in our quest to share our beautiful and epic stories with the world! 
P.S. Since Proximity is a 501(c)(3) non-profit, your contribution is tax deductible!
